content.question: For time <math alttext="t greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acceleration of an object moving in a straight line is given by <math alttext="a, of t, equals, the natural log of, open parenthesis, 3 plus, t to the fourth power, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the net change in velocity from time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to time <math alttext="t equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts
